title: 111_hr4070
content: Reform of biodiesel income tax incentives under Section 40A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes amendments related to biodiesel production. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code is $1.00 per gallon of biodiesel produced and sold for various purposes. Small producers receive an increased credit of 10 cents per gallon for the first 15,000,000 gallons produced. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code provides a credit of $1.00 per gallon of biodiesel produced. Small producers can receive an increased credit of 10 cents per gallon for the first 15,000,000 gallons produced. The credit amount is reduced if other benefits are received under different sections of the code. Biodiesel is defined as liquid fuel derived from biomass meeting specific requirements. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code provides a credit for biodiesel produced in the United States from raw feedstock. If biodiesel is not used as fuel, a tax is imposed on the person who received the credit. The credit is limited to biodiesel produced in the United States. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code provides a credit for biodiesel produced in the United States from raw feedstock. The credit is limited to biodiesel with connection to the United States, and certain rules apply for transfers between biodiesel production facilities, terminals, and refineries. Definitions and special rules apply for small biodiesel producers. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code provides a credit for biodiesel produced in the United States from raw feedstock. Special rules apply for small biodiesel producers with a productive capacity not exceeding 60,000,000 gallons. Aggregation rules apply for controlled groups of corporations and common control entities. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code applies limitations at the entity and partner level. Productive capacity is allocated among multiple persons in a facility. Regulations prevent individuals from benefiting over 60,000,000 gallons directly or indirectly, or more than 15,000,000 gallons in a taxable year. Small biodiesel credits can be allocated to cooperative patrons. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code has limitations at the entity and partner level. Productive capacity is allocated among multiple persons in a facility, with regulations preventing individuals from benefiting over 60,000,000 gallons directly or indirectly, or more than 15,000,000 gallons in a taxable year. Small biodiesel credits can be allocated to cooperative patrons based on business done with or for them. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code has limitations at the entity and partner level. The election for apportionment must be designated in a written notice to patrons during the payment period. The credit not apportioned to patrons is included in the organization's taxable year amount, while the credit apportioned to patrons is included in the patrons' first taxable year amount ending after the payment period. The biodiesel fuels credit under Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code has limitations at the entity and partner level. The organization must notify patrons during the payment period about the apportionment of the credit. If the organization's credit amount is less than shown on the return, the excess reduction not apportioned to patrons is treated as an increase in tax. Renewable diesel is treated similarly to biodiesel for tax purposes, with exceptions outlined. Renewable diesel is defined as liquid fuel derived from biomass meeting specific EPA registration requirements. The Environmental Protection Agency established fuel additives under the Clean Air Act. Renewable diesel includes fuel derived from biomass meeting specific EPA requirements and Department of Defense or ASTM specifications for aviation fuel. This section does not apply after December 31, 2014. Materials specification for aviation turbine fuel. Termination of this section after December 31, 2014. Clerical Amendment to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section regarding biodiesel production will apply after December 31, 2009. The biodiesel credit under section 6426 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide a $1.00 credit for each gallon of biodiesel produced and sold for specific purposes outlined in the amendment. Definitions in this subsection align with those in section 40A. The biodiesel credit under section 6426 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide a $1.00 credit for each gallon of biodiesel produced and sold for specific purposes outlined in the amendment. Definitions align with section 40A. The credit can be claimed by registered terminals or refineries under certain conditions, but not on fuel previously claimed by a biodiesel producer. The subsection expires after December 31, 2014. Amendments to subsection (e) of section 6427 include changes to the payment of the biodiesel credit. The biodiesel credit under section 6426 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide a $1.00 credit for each gallon of biodiesel produced and sold for specific purposes outlined in the amendment. Definitions align with section 40A. The credit can be claimed by registered terminals or refineries under certain conditions, but not on fuel previously claimed by a biodiesel producer. Amendments include changes to the payment of the biodiesel credit. The tax exemption for biodiesel transfers between registered facilities is amended. Producer registration requirements and recapture rules are also updated in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax implications for alcohol fuel mixtures and biodiesel production are outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If alcohol is separated from the mixture or used for non-fuel purposes, a tax is imposed based on the applicable amount and gallons of alcohol. Similarly, a tax of $1 per gallon is imposed if biodiesel is not used for specified purposes. All relevant laws and penalties apply to these taxes. The heading of section 6426 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include alcohol fuel mixtures, biodiesel production, and alternative fuel mixtures. These amendments will apply to biodiesel sold or used after December 31, 2009. SEC. 3. Biodiesel is now considered taxable fuel under the Internal Revenue Code. This amendment applies to biodiesel transactions occurring six months after the enactment of the Act.
